text: To be able to replicate the experiment we should know:\n1. The size and material of the container used. Specify the amount of vinegar to be added to each container and whether it covers the sample in its entirety. Determine the drying process, at what temperature the samples are allowed to dry.

You would need to know whether the samples should be submerged in the vinegar, or the amount of vinegar used would be useful a better description of the objects, since the amount of surface area of the same can affect the results.

by noting that each material was placed in the container the mass had a reaction of difference, but among the different types the wood highlighted since there was no alteration of mass and achieved to have its great difference
After 24 hours it is the same thing, let it dry, repeat each.

1st Weigh each of the four samples before spilling vinegar to get the initial mass.\n\n2. Weigh each of the four samples after letting them dry, to obtain the final mass. Remains the final mass of the final mass to obtain the change of mass of each sample.
For each procedure you can observe the amount of time acquired and the result of each experiment consists of different results, with more consistency or not.
We’ll need to explain what the results are and what ingredients we don’t share.

I doubt the wood. Was it treated with chemicals? Because if not, it should have absorbed more liquid and therefore increased its mass since that is one of the characteristics of wood. I don’t think 30 minutes was enough for the wood to evaporate the liquid and I should have seen more difference. On the other hand, it would have been more interesting if they did the experiment using samples that had the initial mass. This makes it easier to compare results. Finally, it is important to clean the samples since the use of vinegar will surely "clean" the samples from debris and therefore there is a difference after leaving to dry.
The amount of vinegar used in each experiment.

To replicate the experiment I would add:
- a weight to carry out the exact measurement of the samples both before and after the experiment
- describe the shape of the samples studied
- determine the specific amount of vinegar to be placed in each container, so that each sample has the same amount
- mention why these samples are being chosen and what is the objective
What is the material we put with the samples and why do we use that particular material?\nWhat does the material do with the samples? Why does the mass of each sample change?
Quantity of vinegar, ambient temperature and water concentration.

The mass or volume of vinegar thrown into the containers, the difference between the mass of the container with vinegar before placing the sample and after placing the sample and the materials used for the study

First of all, you would need to duplicate the exact procedure with the same material and the same amount of vinagra in order to verify the results obtained.  Once replicated it can be compared between the two results and concluded with the average difference between the masses.

You would need to know how much vinegar to add to each sample, and whether the amount of vinegar should be relative to the sample mass at the beginning of the experiment. It is also necessary to know what the purpose of the experiment is in order to be able to use the results to draw conclusions, it is likely that calculations will be made. Temperature can also be important in experiments, you would need to know the temperature at which the original experiment was carried out to correctly replicate the results.
